III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4129 Institutions serving developmentally
Section disabled youth; written procedures.
Description (1) An institution providing care to developmentally disabled
residents shall require staff to follow written procedures for
bathing, feeding, toilet training, and daily activities of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff won't check youth’s brief before they go to bed. Staff has
said to just let the overnight staff worry about it. This has
happened on several occasions.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 3/4/24.
Complainant reported she received the complaint from an
anonymous source and did not have any contact information for
the person who made the complaint. Complainant reported there
were no youth or staff names associated to this allegation. Since
the original complaint source was anonymous and no contact
information was provided, no further details could be requested.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at a
different facility on 3/5/24, at this facility on 3/15/24, and via
phone on 4/10/24. CA reported it is obvious when a youth has
soiled their briefs, and she hasn’t heard about or received
complaints about any staff neglecting to change a youth’s briefs
before they go to bed. CA reported Youth A and Youth C are the
two youth at the facility who wear briefs. Youth A always wears
briefs and Youth C only wears briefs at night. CA reported
because the youth are teenagers, it is not appropriate for staff to
randomly checking youth’s briefs as a standard practice. However,
each youth in briefs has an Activities of Daily Living (ADL) plan
and/or a bathroom protocol. Part of each youth’s ADL is to take
them to the bathroom before bed, and it is expected staff would
change a youth’s brief at that time. CA reported all staff receive
on-going training and feedback about bathroom protocols and
ADLs from BCBA (Board-Certified Behavior Analyst) staff during
frequent observations of staff & youth interactions and data
collection throughout their employment.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/5/24.
Staff 1 reported Youth C is non-verbal, but when he has
accidents, he gets up quickly and let’s staff know because he
doesn’t like the feeling. Staff 1 reported Youth A can say
“bathroom” or expresses in another way if he has an accident.
Staff 1 reported both youths have bathroom protocols and ADL
2

plans, which requires them to use the bathroom prior to going to
bed. If staff notice they have soiled themselves prior to bed, it
would be the responsibility of those staff to change their briefs at
that time. Staff 1 reported she has not witnessed or heard of any
concerns regarding staff not following these protocols or not
addressing any youth’s bathroom needs.
Staff 2 and Staff 3 were interviewed face to face at the facility
on 3/5/24. Both staff reported all youth, including Youth A and
Youth C, do their ADL plans right before bed, so if they have a
soiled brief, it gets changed then. Both staff reported Youth A and
Youth C are supposed to be taken to the bathroom every hour
during waking hours and if they were soiled, they would be
cleaned up and their brief would be changed. Both staff reported
they have never witnessed or heard of those duties get pushed
onto another shift or a youth’s bathroom needs going
unaddressed.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/15/24.
Staff 5 reported the same information as Staff 2 and Staff 3. Staff
5 also reported there are times third shift staff have had to help
with ADL plans if second shift is running behind, but it only
happens if there’s an escalated youth or they’re short staffed. Staff
5 reported it hasn’t happened often or consistently, and if it
happens, it is always communicated in an appropriate way rather
than being pushed off to third shift.
Staff 6 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/15/24.
Staff 6 reported she has never heard of or witnessed any staff
intentionally leave youth soiled, not address their ADL plan,
neglect a youth’s bathroom needs, or leave a youth’s soiled brief
for third shift to handle.
Student 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
3/15/24. Student 1 reported she is part of the clinical staff, and
they do frequent observations of ADL plans. Student 1 reported as
part of those observations, she has never seen any staff disregard
a youth’s bathroom needs. Student 1 reported she has never
witnessed or heard of any staff leaving a youth’s bathroom needs
for another shift to handle.
Youth A and Youth C are non-verbal and were unable to be
interviewed.
3

DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• ADL (Activities of Daily Living) Policy states these plans
include information on a youth’s bathing, toileting, feeding,
and other individually identified needs. Assistance will be
provided by support and assessment, training, and/or
ongoing support. Staff are to follow the steps as described
in the plan.
• Youth A’s Bathroom Protocol dated 8/9/23 states Youth A
should be using the bathroom once every hour during
waking hours and staff should record bathroom trips on
daily data sheets.
• Youth A’s January 2024 daily logs do not reflect any
concerns about staff not changing youth’s brief as required.
• Youth C’s Bathroom Protocol dated 3/22/23 states staff
should place any soiled clothing items in a nearby laundry
hamper to be washed. Youth C should wear underwear
while at home. At the facility, Youth C will be prompted to
go to the bathroom every 30 minutes during waking hours.
If Youth C independently asks to use the bathroom, staff
will immediately stop the current activity/demand and take
him to the bathroom. Youth C must sit on the toilet for 5
minutes. All data must be entered on a data sheet for every
scheduled sit, self-initiation, and accident.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. No employees had any concerns with
staff not checking any youth’s briefs before bed or leaving a
youth’s bathroom needs for another shift to handle.
Documentation for the youth who wear briefs do not note any
concerns for this occurring.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff used blocking pads to push youth into their room.
4

Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 3/4/24.
Complainant reported she received the complaint from an
anonymous source and did not have any contact information for
the person who made the complaint. Complainant reported this
allegation was specific to Youth A, but there were no staff names
provided with the allegation. Since the original complaint source
was anonymous and no contact information was provided, no
further details could be requested.
Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 were interviewed face to face
separately at the facility on 3/5/24. Staff 5, Staff 6, Student 1
and Student 2 were interviewed face to face separately at the
facility on 3/15/24. They all reported they have never seen or
heard of any staff using a blocking pad to push Youth A into his
room. They all reported Youth A loves being in his room, so they
could not think of any situation in which someone would have to
force him into his room. They all reported the use of force with a
blocking pad is prohibited, and if they would have seen this occur,
they would have reported it.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at a
different facility on 3/5/24, at this facility on 3/15/24, and via
phone on 4/10/24. CA reported blocking pads would be used if a
youth was being aggressive towards staff but shouldn’t ever be
utilized to push a youth. CA reported she has never seen or heard
of any staff utilizing blocking pads to push Youth A into his room.
Youth A was unable to be interviewed because he is non-
verbal.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Youth A case file documents Youth A has resided at this
facility since 1/23/24.
• Blocking Pad Procedures outlines when and how to utilize
blocking pads at the facility. It outlines what are appropriate
techniques when using the blocking pads. It says pushing,
striking, or shoving of someone with the pad is not allowed.
• Great Lakes Center for Autism Treatment and Researched
Licensed Settings Policy Regarding Discipline and
Behavior Management states pushing a youth on any part
of their body is prohibited.
5

Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. All employees interviewed reported
they have never seen or heard of any staff using a blocking pad to
push Youth A into his room.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation One youth is fearful of staff, and this same staff ignores
Behavioral Support Plans (BSP's).
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 3/4/24.
Complainant reported she received the complaint from an
anonymous source and did not have any contact information for
the person who made the complaint. Complainant reported this
allegation only provided a last name for a youth, but not the first
name. Complainant reported there were no staff names provided
with the allegation. Since the original complaint source was
anonymous and no contact information was provided, no further
details could be requested.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were interviewed face to face separately at
the facility on 3/5/24. Both staff stated they have never known
Youth B to be fearful of any staff at the facility. Both reported
Youth B has never complained, stated he was fearful, or reacted
in a way to make them think he was fearful of a staff at the facility.
Both reported they have no knowledge of any staff intentionally
ignoring Youth B’s BSP. Both reported there are times when staff
may forget little pieces of a BSP, but they’re honest mistakes, and
nothing that would be harmful towards a youth.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/5/24.
Staff 3 reported she has never seen or heard of Youth B being
fearful of any staff. Staff 3 reported he demonstrates and
expresses fear towards other youth if they become aggressive,
but not staff. Staff 3 reported she has never seen or heard of
anyone blatantly ignoring Youth B’s BSP. Staff 3 reported one part
of Youth B’s BSP is to watchfully ignore his problem behaviors.
Staff 3 reported she can see how a staff may make an honest
6

mistake in not following it or someone might have seen a staff
ignoring Youth B’s behaviors and misinterpreted the situation.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at a different facility on
3/7/24. Staff 4 reported he worked at this facility from November
2023 until mid-January 2024. Staff 4 reported he never saw or
heard of Youth B demonstrating or expressing any fear towards
him or any other staff at the facility. Staff 4 reported he has never
seen any staff blatantly or intentionally ignore Youth B’s BSP.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/15/24.
Staff 5 reported she has never known Youth B to be fearful of any
staff at the facility. Staff 5 reported some days he just likes some
staff more than others. Staff 5 reported there are times Youth B
expresses he is happy certain staff aren’t working, but there’s no
consistency to which staff he picks each time. Staff 5 reported she
hasn’t seen or heard of any staff intentionally or blatantly not
following Youth B’s BSP.
Staff 6 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/15/24.
Staff 6 reported she has never seen or heard of Youth B showing
or expressing fear towards any staff. Staff 6 reported she has not
seen or heard of any staff ignoring Youth B’s BSP. Staff 6
reported Youth B has a little bag with a timer that goes off every 7
minutes. If he has had good behaviors after the timer going off 4
times, Youth B will get a candy as a prize. Staff 6 reported there
are times when the timer or prize gets missed by staff sometimes,
but this is not a consistent practice by any staff. Staff 6 reported
it’s not intentional when it happens because sometimes staff just
forget because it is busy, or they are focused on other things.
Student 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
3/15/24. Student 1 reported she has never seen Youth B
demonstrate or express fear towards any staff. Student 1 reported
there are times when various staff negate some small nit-picky
components of his BSP, but nothing regarding the well-being
component of his BSP. Student 1 reported Staff 7 disagreed with
some small components of Youth B’s BSP, and the clinical team
frequently received negative feedback from Staff 7. Student 1
reported Staff 7 didn’t do anything rising to the level of a recipient
rights complaint. Student 1 reported the relationship between Staff
7 and Youth B was different, but Staff 7 didn’t do anything to make
it that way. Student 1 reported there were times Youth B would
repeat “[Staff 7’s] not here” in a loud tone, and normally Youth B is
louder about things he has anxiety about. Student 1 reported
when Youth B would engage in targeted or aggressive behavior, it
7

was typically towards Staff 7. However, Student 1 noted there are
not a lot of male staff at the facility, so that could have been a
reason for Youth B’s behaviors towards Staff 7.
Student 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
3/15/24. Student 2 reported she has never seen Youth B
demonstrate or express fear towards any staff. Student 2 reported
Youth B had a different relationship with Staff 7, but she isn’t sure
it was a lack of trust, dislike, or something else. Student 2 reported
Youth B would aggress towards Staff 7 more than anyone else.
Student 2 reported even after Staff 7 hadn’t worked at the facility
for a month, Youth B would still fixate on repeating “[Staff 7’s] not
here” or “Is [Staff 7] coming?”, which is a symptom of his
diagnosis. Student 2 reported it was clear Staff 7 cared about the
youth at the facility, but it was difficult to work with him because it
was obvious, he didn’t care as much about the BSPs. Student 2
reported Staff 7 treated the BSPs as a choice and not something
he had to run each shift. Student 2 reported when she would
provide Staff 7 with feedback, he would become frustrated and
say, “it’s easier for me to do it this way”. Student 2 reported she
would frequently have to remind Staff 7 the BSP was a legal
document and needed to be run correctly. Student 2 reported Staff
7 would comply with the most important parts of the BSP, which
were the well-being portions of Youth B’s BSP. However, Staff 7
would struggle to consistently implement the behavior reduction
portions, transition warnings and proactive strategies of Youth B’s
BSP. Student 2 reported Staff 7’s feelings or actions regarding not
following the BSP would not rise to the level of a recipient rights
worthy complaint or be considered harmful to Youth B.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed face to face at
another facility on 3/7/24. PM reported Youth B is very
expressive and very anxious. PM reported around mid-January
2024, he received concerns from Staff 3 about observations she
had regarding Staff 4’s interactions with Youth B. Staff 3 reported
Staff 4 appeared frustrated by Youth B’s constant questions and
behaviors. PM reported no one knows Youth B’s BSP better than
Youth B and it takes him a while to build rapport with staff. PM
reported they didn’t feel that it rose to the level of a recipient rights
violation, but they did provide Staff 4 with feedback within his
performance evaluation.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at a
different facility on 3/5/24 and at this facility on 3/15/24. CA
reported Youth B’s last name matches the Complainant’s
information. CA reported some of Youth B’s scripting behaviors
8

can possibly be seen as fearful. CA reported it’s in his BSP to
ignore some of these behaviors because the more you talk to him
about his past trauma, it’ll escalate him further. CA reported if the
complainant wasn’t familiar with his BSP, they might think staff
were just generally ignoring him. CA reported she hasn’t seen or
heard of Youth B expressing or demonstrating any fear towards
any staff. When asked about Staff 7, CA reported he was having
some performance issues, which consisted of mainly bumping
heads with Staff 3. CA reported Staff 7 was disciplined for not
following BSPs for youth and not documenting program data. CA
reported it is unreasonable to say staff are supposed to run a
youth’s BSP 100% of the time, so goals for all BSPs are expected
to be 80% implementation or higher. CA reported Staff 7 was
never in blatant disregard of Youth B’s BSP, but it was clear he
didn’t value the BSPs and had a hard time understanding how the
BSPs helped youth improve their skills and behaviors. CA
reported Staff 7 felt youth should be making more progress at a
faster pace than they were, but he didn’t always document data to
show progress was being made. CA reported Staff 7’s non-
compliances with the BSP were never neglectful to any youth,
caused harm to any youth, etc.
An attempt was made to interview Youth B face to face at the
facility on 3/15/24. Due to Youth B’s diagnoses and abilities,
Youth B was unable to answer any questions, and only repeated
back everything this Consultant was asking.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Youth B case file noted he has been at the facility since
4/17/23.
• Youth B’s Behavior Treatment Plan (a.k.a. BSP) (updated
7/11/23) outlines Youth B’s history, diagnoses,
medications, assessed behaviors, target behaviors,
monitored behaviors, proactive strategies, reactive
strategies, restrictive activities, and data/documentation
required.
• Great Lakes Center for Autism Treatment and Researched
Licensed Settings Policy Regarding Discipline and
Behavior Management states each youth will have a
behavior treatment plan developed that addresses how
staff are to respond to that individual’s target behavior.
When a youth demonstrates a behavior not accounted for
in the plan, or when the prescribed response cannot be
implemented, staff will be required to use their discretion as
9

to how to respond to the behavior. The policy outlines
appropriate responses that could be used in these
situations.
• Staff 4 has one disciplinary action in his employee file,
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 4 received training on
the discipline/behavior management policy during new hire
orientation in August 2023 and was trained on Youth B’s
BSP on 11/14/23.
• Staff 7 has one disciplinary action in his employee file,
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 7 received training on
the discipline/behavior management policy during new hire
orientation in October 2020 and was trained on Youth B’s
BSP in May 2023.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. No staff interviewed expressed any
concerns about Youth B being afraid of any staff. Student 1,
Student 2, and CA reported Staff 7 would express his dislike for
BSPs, not understand BSPs, or not follow some of the
prompts/rewards/etc. for Youth B’s BSP. However, they all
reported Staff 7 never ignored the main components of Youth B’s
BSP or did anything that would be considered harmful or a
recipient’s rights violation towards Youth B.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
April 11, 2024
Shannon (Shay) Mavis Date
Licensing Consultant
